answers.answer: When did you last have your blood pressure checked?  If you have very low blood pressure this can cause the problems from sitting to standing.  This is one avenue you can explore.  I am not entirely familiar with your medications but there could also be side effects from these.  If you have polycysic ovarian sydrome, as you may know you are at increased risk from diabetes.  So you need to have yourself checked for this regularly.  Alongside this is the risk of peripheral vascular disease, which means the blood supply to your extremities can be interrupted, which will cause numbness.  Alternatively there may be an entirely unrelated issue causing these symptoms, and you may need input from a neurologist. Basically in answer to your question my advice is yes, tell your doctor.  Maybe if they are open minded even suggest some of the above.  If your doctor is good and knows you well they may have the answer to the best way forward.  Don't ever be put off seeking help because you think a problem is too trivial.  Particularly with your diagnoses, there is no problem which you should ignore.  So please get help, get your blood pressure checked, get your blood sugar levels checked, and then see if these yield answers or you need to look on to specialist referrals.  Wish you good health and let us know if you get a result!

Thank you for the information.  Actually my blood pressure is usually pretty low to average.  I just had it checked about 2 weeks ago and it was 119 over 40, but I checked it right after a workout.  I have always had issues with low blood pressure so I am definitely going to look into that.  I was also unaware of peripheral vascular disease, but I did know about the diabetes.  I have my sugar and thyroid levels checked so often that I am on a first name basis with my phlebotomist.  I see an endocrinologist on a regular basis.  She is person who diagnosed me with the thyroid and the PCOS issue.I went ahead and set up a doc appointment for tomorrow at 4:30.  I am sure I will get sent to a specialist, because I have to first see a general practitioner, before I can get a referral.  I will keep you updated and thanks again for the information.

question: In the past 2-3 weeks, I have been experiencing an issue with dizziness and faintness when standing up.  It is usually when I have been sitting for more than 2 minutes.  When I stand up I have to hold on to something not to lose my balance.  I feel weak almost like I am having issues with my blood sugar.  I have been tested for diabetes a couple weeks ago and I am in the good range.  I am also having issues with numbness in my right foot.  It is to the point where I am stumbling and I am having issues wearing my dress shoes.  I am not sure if these issues are remotely related, but my health is better than it has ever been otherwise.In January, I weighed 267 pounds and as of today I weigh 216.4 pounds.   I am eating really healthy, no drinking, and exercising at least 5 times a week if not more.  I am a smoker, but I smoke about 8-10 cigarettes a day (so about a half a pack).  I get enough sleep as well.  I am currently on 1500mg of Metformine a day for Poly Cystic Ovarian Syndrome.  Then I take .5 of Synthroid one day a week and .25 six days a week.  I do have an issue with my thryoid, which is the reason I am taking the Synthroid.My overall question is:  Should I see a doctor about these issues?  or are they something I can just overlook?  I hate going to the doctor for no reason, but I injured my foot last night because it feel asleep after a minute and half of not moving it.  Can someone please help me?  Any incite would be wonderful.
title: Should I be concered? and are these issues related?
